content:
I had the opportunity to work closely with Harsh Mishra for several months, and I can confidently say he is one of the most promising early career engineers I’ve come across in recent years.
Harsh brings an impressive mix of technical depth, curiosity, and ownership that is rare to see in someone at his experience level. During our time working together, he consistently demonstrated strong capability in Site Reliability Engineering and DevOps practices, particularly across Kubernetes, Terraform, AWS, and CI/CD pipelines. His contributions went beyond execution, Harsh showed a clear understanding of system reliability principles and often took initiative to improve the overall developer experience through automation and smarter tooling.
What stood out to me most was his ability to think holistically about systems, understanding not just how to fix a problem, but why it occurred and how to prevent it in the future. His problem solving approach, combined with a calm and methodical attitude under pressure, made him an invaluable contributor to the team.
Harsh has the mindset of a lifelong learner and the technical foundation to grow into a strong engineering leader. I have no doubt he will continue to make meaningful impact wherever he goes.

content:
I always try to find time to work and learn something new. Usually, most of these pet-projects don’t see the light of day. They are, however, great opportunities to try something in the real world and learn from it. This is not an exhaustive list. There’s a graveyard you can always visit on my Github.
Pychanio Active Go to Docs Get It On PyPI An Opinionated Python Concurrency Library, that brings Golang like select-case DSL and channels to Python’s asyncio. It offers a full interop with Python asyncio.
Supports both unidirectional and full-duplex channels. Supports blocking and non blocking sends Supports timeouts in select case blocks. Support for nil channels Support for sentinels to send signals such as HEARTBEAT, DONE, CANCEL etc. Source harsh098/pychanio Go-style channels and select blocks for asyncio in Python. Python 6 0 IaC and GitOps Pipeline for Kubeadm Cluster over Amazon EC2 Boilerplate Quickstart This project allows users to create a GitOps Pipeline using Terraform for Infra Provisioning and Ansible for Configuration Management to create clusters using Kubeadm over Amazon EC2.
Used Terraform for infrastructure provision and Ansible for configuration management. The Automation is handled via a Continuous Deployment (CD) Pipeline using GitHub Actions. The CD Pipeline uses Keyless Authentication to AWS via Github OIDC Provider for enhanced security Implemented the Least Privilege Principle Model to secure the Pipeline The Action publishes the Kubeconfig for connecting to the Kubernetes cluster to AWS Secrets Manager. Implemented Remote Terraform State Management using AWS S3 as the backend Modularized Terraform configuration into modules, which allows users to customize the deployment easily by editing the .tfvars files. The project uses Ansible Providers for Terraform to generate inventory files dynamically. Source harsh098/kubeadm-cluster-with-terraform-ansible-ec2 Terraform Module to create a kubeadm cluster over AWS EC2 using Terraform, Ansible and Github Actions HCL 0 1 Keyless AWS EKS Authentication Plugin for GitHub Actions Stable Receives Occasional Updates A secure keyless sign-on solution for AWS EKS clusters within Github Actions CI/CD pipelines. Addressed the lack of support for AWS CLI v2 in existing actions, enhancing security and future-proofing deployments.
